Industrial Chemistry “Toso Montanari” Department University of Bologna Viale Risorgimento 4 Bologna 40136 Italy This research investigates the influence of hydro-soluble polymeric ligands on the properties and catalytic performance of colloidal gold nanoparticles supported on activated carbon. The aim was to understand how polymer molecular weight affects Au nanoparticle size, dispersion, and catalytic activity, providing a framework for optimizing catalysis from the design phase. Three polymeric ligands (PVA, PEO, and PVAm) with different molecular weights were synthesized via controlled chain-transfer-to-solvent reactions and used to prepare supported colloidal Au nanoparticles through sol-immobilization. The results demonstrated that molecular weight significantly impacts Au nanoparticle size. Moreover, catalytic activity was assessed using the reduction of 4-nitrophenol as a model reaction. As polymer molecular weight increased, the apparent kinetic constant (kapp) decreased, particularly for PEO-based catalysts, where kapp decreased by an order of magnitude. Higher molecular weight polymers also formed dense polymeric "brushes," hindering reagent diffusion and reducing catalytic performance. Further analysis of Au/polymer weight ratios revealed that decreasing polymer content improved catalytic activity, particularly in Au-PVAm catalysts. The findings underscore the crucial role of polymeric ligands in colloidal nanocatalyst design, emphasizing the need to investigate the metal-polymer interface to optimize catalyst properties. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Colloidal au nanoparticles Effect of choice of polymer Hydrogenation of 4-nitrophenol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Several efforts have been devoted to developing more efficient methods for preparing metal nanoparticles with controlled shapes, sizes, low polydispersity, high purity, and good stability in specific dispersion media, especially focusing on the synthesis of monodispersed nanoparticles [1–4]. The application of polymers in metal nanoparticle synthesis has attracted significant interest due to a better understanding of the stabilization processes. By choosing the process parameters it can be possible to control both quantum size and surface-to-volume ratio of nanosized particles. At the nanoscopic level, interactions of nanoparticles with surrounding molecules play a crucial role in determining their properties. Various strategies for anchoring polymers to metal surfaces have been investigated, revealing a strong correlation between the properties of the resulting materials (e.g., stability and surface chemistry modification) and the specific features of the polymers used [5–7]. In this context, it is essential to report and discuss how the characteristics of the polymer ligand, such as molecular weight or functional groups, can directly influence not only the topology of nanomaterials but also the size and electronic properties of the metal-polymer system. The molecular weight of the polymer ligand plays a critical role in determining the overall structure and morphology of the metal-polymer nanomaterial. Generally, higher molecular weight polymers tend to form thicker and more robust coatings on the metal surface due to their increased chain length and entanglement. This results, in a denser polymer layer that can improve the stability and mechanical properties of the final material. On the other hand, lower molecular weight polymers may lead to more disordered or loosely bound coatings, potentially affecting the stability and long-term performance of the metal-polymer system [8–10]. Furthermore, experimental evidence suggest that the molecular weight can also impact the shape and size distribution of metal nanoparticles. Li and Komarneni illustrate the correlation between the size distribution of nickel nanoparticles and the molecular weight of PVP used during the synthesis [11]. Moreover, the molecular weight of polymers can also influence the shape of the formed nanoparticles as described from Song et al. [12]. It was reported that the shape of Ag NPs was dependent on the choice of PVP's molecular weights. Adsorbing organic molecules onto the surface of metal nanoparticles (NPs) has a significant impact on the interactions between the NPs and the substrates they catalyse the reaction, therefore affecting the catalytic performance in terms of activity, stability and yield to the desired products. This means that the protective ligands covering the NPs cannot be ignored, as they play a crucial role. This can occur through mechanisms like reducing the accessibility of the reactants to the metal surface and acting as a dynamic shell that adjusts both activity and selectivity. Consequently, the way adsorption is controlled can influence the selectivity of products in reactions that are sensitive to the structure of the catalyst. The steric effect can also be understood as imposing hindrance to reactants with intricate molecular geometry. The dense arrangement of surface ligands can modify the manner in which reactants bind to catalytic sites by altering the types of binding or specific functional groups involved. This effect arises due to the crowding of surface ligands, which in turn affects the interaction between reactants and the catalytic sites [8,13–15]. A direct example was reported by Campisi et al., which observed a decreased rate of benzaldehyde decarbonylation when utilizing PVA-protected Pd nanoparticles in contrast to unprotected Pd nanoparticles [16]. As a result, the selectivity towards aldehyde was heightened, and the undesirable overoxidation to benzoic acid was impeded by the presence of PVA. A direct correlation between the chain length and packing density of SH-PEG (thiolated polyethylene glycol) and the catalytic activity of Au nanoparticles (NPs) was observed from Ansar and co-workers for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol [17]. The study revealed that a high surface coverage of low molecular weight PEG (1 kDa) led to a complete inhibition of the catalytic activity of Au NPs. The main objective of this research activity is to deeply investigate the role of molecular weight of polymeric hydro-soluble ligands in determining the final properties (e.g., size and active phase dispersion) and catalytic activity (e.g., conversion and stability) of colloidal gold nanoparticles supported on activated carbon. The aim is to rationalize the effects of polymers, providing a toolbox for tuning catalytic performances starting from catalyst design [18]. Additionally, exploring the potential to enhance the conversion and selectivity of specific reactions through customized polymeric ligands could change the approach to catalyst preparation. 2 Experimental section 2–2′-Azo-bis-isobutyronitrile (AIBN), vinyl acetate, N-vinyl-formamide, sodium hydroxide were commercially available chemicals and were used for the synthesis of polymeric ligands without further purification process. Tetrachlorauric acid (HAuCl4·3H2O), sodium borohydride (NaBH4), activated carbon NORIT SX1 G, sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 96 %), 4-nitrophenol, PEO1, PEO2, PEO3 and PEO4 were used to prepare colloidal metal nanoparticles and to conduct the catalytic tests. All products were employed without further purification processes. 2.1 Synthesis of polymeric ligands The procedure to obtain polymeric stabilizers and the relative characterizations were reported in supplementary materials. 2.2 Supported colloidal gold-nanoparticles preparation A colloidal gold solution was prepared by dissolving 0.76 g (1.9 mmol) of HAuCl4·3H2O in 200 mL of distilled water. Then 5.5 mL were taken from the initial solution and diluted to 385 mL of distilled water, to which was added a 1 % w/w polymer aqueous solution to obtain Au:polymer weight ratio of 1:0.65. After 3 min, a freshly prepared aqueous solution of NaBH4 (Au:NaBH4 = 1:5 mol/mol) was added. A red Au(0) sol was immediately formed as the Au solution was analyzed by UV–Vis to detect the formation of the plasmon surface Au peak and to verify the absence of the Au precursor. The colloidal solution was stirred for 30 min, and, at the end, the Au colloidal nanoparticles were immobilized by adding the activated carbon (AC) under vigorous stirring. The solution was acidified at pH 2 by sulfuric acid. The amount of support was calculated to have a nominal metal loading of 1 wt.%. The mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature. Then, the catalyst was filtered and washed several times with distilled water until a neutral pH was reached. After drying overnight at room temperature, the solids were dried at 80 °C in an oven for 4 h in static air conditions. 2.3 Catalytic tests 2.3.1 Calibration test To carry out the UV–Vis experiments the extinction coefficient was calculated primarily by preparing five solutions of different 4-NP concentrations (1.5·10−4 M, 1.0·10−4 M, 5.0·10−4 M, 2.5·10−5 M, 1.0·10−4 M) and 4.5·10−4 M in NaBH4 and measuring their absorbance using an in situ Agilent Cary 3500 UV–Vis Spectrometer equipped with 1 cm path cuvette. In agreement with the literature, the average extinction coefficient derived from the calibration curves repeated three times is 18,900 M−1 cm−1 [19,20]. 2.3.2 Catalytic reduction of 4-Nitrophenol The catalytic 4-nitrophenol reduction with a fresh solution of NaBH4 was employed as a model reaction to investigate the effect of the polymeric stabilizers on the catalytic performances. The reaction was carried out in an aqueous phase under mild conditions of pressure and temperature (25 °C). The standard reaction was accomplished by preparing 4-NP aqueous solutions (2.0·10−4 M) in a 25 mL volumetric flask. Then, a fresh solution of NaBH4 (9.0·10−4 M) in 25 mL was prepared with a molar ratio of 4-NP:NaBH4 of 1:45 mol/mol in order to uphold a pseudo-first-order kinetic model [21,22]. Moreover, a reference NaBH4 solution in a 25 mL flask (4.5·10−4 M) for the UV–Vis measurements was prepared. The following experimental protocol was used: the catalyst (4 mg) was first added inside a beaker, and then the 4-NP solution was added. Immediately after, 25 mL of NaBH4 solution (9.0·10−4 M) was added and this time was considered the start of the reaction. After mixing, an aliquot was withdrawn from the beaker and poured in a quartz cuvette, and then subsequently inserted in the UV–Vis spectrometer's stage. After the NaBH4 addition, 2.5 min were passed as induction time before starting the measurement. The optical absorbance of the reaction was set to be automatically evaluated every 2.5 min for 25 cycles to measure the decrease in 4-nitrophenol concentration as a function of reaction time at 25 °C. 2.3.3 Kinetic data elaboration The 4-nitrophenol reduction was studied considering a pseudo-first order kinetic model where the apparent kinetic constant (kapp) was obtained with the following equation: − l n C C 0 = k a p p t The concentration values have been determined using the Lambert-Beer equation. The slope of the graph obtained by correlating the reaction time with the logarithm of the ratio between the concentration C (at the time t) and the initial one (C0) allows to evaluate the kinetic constant of the process. The data calculated were used to obtain the reaction percentage conversion (X%) by the following relationship: X % = C 0 − C t C 0 · 100 2.4 Characterization The polymer structures were characterized, and their structures were confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy using a Varian “Mercury 400″ spectrometer, operating at 400 MHz. Tetramethylsilane (TMS) was used as an internal reference standard. All polymeric ligands were characterized by Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR), acquiring the spectra through an ATR-IR Bruker Alpha I spectrometer. The molecular weights of the polymers were determined by gel permeation chromatography (GPC). The analyses were carried out using two 300 mm 5MXL columns with different ranges of molecular weights that they are able to assess. The samples were solubilized in THF and the analysis was performed with a flow rate of 1 mL/min at 20°C. The calibration of the column was carried out with monodisperse polystyrene commercial standards. The evaluation of LSPR (localized surface plasmon resonance) peak was carried out by an Agilent Cary 3500 UV–Vis Spectrometer. Colloidal solutions were analysed by dynamic light scattering (DLS) measures, registered by using a Malvern Zetasizer Nano ZS instrument. The hydrodynamic volume was carried out using a standard polystyrene cell at 25 °C, while for the zeta potential analysis a capillary polycarbonate cell equipped with electrodes at 25 °C was employed. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a TEM Talos F200X instrument. TEM images were processed by using the ImageJ to determine average particle size and particle size distribution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded on a Physical Electronic spectrometer (PHI Versa Probe II) using monochromatic Al Kα radiation (52.8 W, 15 kV, 1486.6 eV) and a dual-beam charge neutralizer for analysing the core-level signals of the elements of interest with a hemispherical multichannel detector. The samples’ spectra were recorded with a constant pass energy value at 29.35 eV and a beam diameter of 100 µm. The energy scale was calibrated using Cu 2p3/2, Ag 3d5/2, and Au 4f7/2 photoelectron lines at 932.7, 368.2, and 83.95 eV, respectively. The X-ray photoelectron spectra obtained were analysed using PHI SmartSoft software and processed using the MultiPak 9.6.0.15 package. The binding energy values were referenced to C 1 s signal at 284.5 eV Shirley-type background and Gauss–Lorentz curves were used to determine the binding energies. Atomic concentration percentages of the characteristic elements were determined considering the corresponding area sensitivity factor for the different measured spectral regions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of polymeric ligands To comprehensively investigate the effects of the molecular weight of polymeric ligands on the catalytic performance of colloidal gold nanoparticles, three distinct series of ligands were used, each characterized by different molecular weights and functional groups. PVA and PVAm ligands were synthesized via solution free-radical polymerization of vinyl acetate and N-vinyl formamide, respectively, followed by a post-polymerization hydrolysis reaction to obtain the final polymers. To control the molecular weights, different solvent mixtures were employed during the chain growth phase as reported in our previous work [23–25]. In the case of PVA-based ligands to confirm the effect of the solvent on the obtained molecular weight, GPC analysis was carried out on poly(vinyl acetate) using the experimental parameters described in the SI. In Table 1 are reported the molecular weights and the related solvent mixtures used during the synthesis for each sample before and after hydrolysis step. PVA stabilizers were subjected to spectroscopic analysis (1H NMR and FT-IR) to confirm their structures, the main signals were reported in the supplementary section. Instead, poly(N-vinyl formamide) molecular weights were evaluated by capillary viscometry applying the equations described in SI. In Fig. 1 was reported the Huggins and Kraemer plots obtained by relating the concentration values to inherent (ηinh) and reduced viscosities (ηred), respectively. The intrinsic viscosity (η) was graphically determined by the intersection of the two lines and the values of the viscometric molecular weight (Mv) was calculated and reported in Table 2 using the following Mark-Houwink equation: [ η ] = 5.43 · 10 − 4 M v 0.715 The data highlighted the same trend observed for the PVA ligands, during the polymerization in ethyl alcohol, the growing chain can easily abstract hydrogen from a molecule of the solvent, which led to a low molecular weight product. Instead, in the presence of t-butanol in the solvent mixture, high molecular weight was obtained due to the high steric hindrance of the hydroxylic group on the tertiary carbon atom. Despite employing the same solvents, the range of weights obtained is slightly different from the PVA systems, likely due to the different chemical nature of the involved monomers. All samples were fully hydrolyzed following the methodology described in SI and the calculated molecular weights after the hydrolysis step was reported in the following Table 2. The chemical structures were confirmed by 1H NMR and FT-IR spectroscopies reported in SI. To complete the investigation, several commercially available PEG ligands with different molecular weights were employed. The molecular weights of the selected polymers were confirmed using a combination of 13C NMR and viscosity determination. NMR spectroscopy has been employed to determine the molecular weight of macromolecules with short chains, following the strategy reported in SI. Instead, the values of the viscometric molecular weight (Mv) were obtained using the Mark-Houwink equation with the following parameters (Fig. 2 ) and the results are reported in Table 3 . [ η ] = 1.25 · 10 − 4 M v 0.78 3.2 Synthesis and characterization of nanostructured catalysts Nanostructured catalysts were prepared using sol-immobilization methods, with activated carbon as the support material. Following the procedure outlined in 2.2, the resulting colloidal solutions containing the synthesized polymeric ligands as stabilizers were characterized by spectroscopic techniques such as UV–visible spectroscopy, dynamic light scattering (DLS), and electrophoretic light scattering (ELS). For the heterogeneous catalysts, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to assess the oxidation state of the nanoparticles, while transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was utilized to determine their particle size in terms of mean particle size and particle size distribution. Moreover, combining TEM and DLS analysis an evaluation of polymeric layer thickness (PLT) around metal nanoparticles was possible by applying the following equation: P L T ( n m ) = d D L S − d T E M Here, the primary characterization of each polymer-metal system is presented, culminating in a comparative analysis aimed at assessing the influence of molecular weight on the size and the structural properties of the nanomaterials. The colloidal nanoparticles were investigated controlling the evolution of the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) peak, observed via UV-visible spectroscopy, as an indicator to assess the formation of gold nanoparticles and investigate changes in their size [26,27]. By analyzing the absorption peaks overlaid in Fig. 3 A corresponding to LSPR peaks of the colloidal solution obtained using PVA with different molecular weights, it's possible to observe how this parameter can influence the mean particle size of the Au nanoparticles. An increase in macromolecular chain length leads to the formation of larger Au nanoparticles. These qualitative observations from the UV–vis spectra were further confirmed by TEM analysis (Fig. 3B-S1). Furthermore, polymeric layer thickness calculated resulted the same for each sample investigated. To gain further insights into the PVA-based materials, XPS spectroscopy was employed to assess the percentage of gold on the catalysts' surface, as well as the oxidation state of the metal species involved. As shown in Table 4 , all samples exhibit typical binding energies (BE) associated with gold in the Au0 state (Figure S3) [21,28]. These results demonstrate the significant impact of molecular weight on the size and distribution of active metal species on the catalyst surface. To continue investigating the effect of molecular weight (Mw) on nanoparticle properties, commercially available PEOs with different molecular weights were used to prepare colloidal gold nanoparticles. Once again, the red shift in the LSPR (Localized Surface Plasmon Resonance) indicated an increase in the nanoparticle size of Au. The overlapped peak shown in Fig. 4 A demonstrates a shift in the signals for systems with higher molecular weights, consistent with the results observed for PVA-based catalysts. To further validate these findings, TEM images were obtained, and the calculated values of mean particle size are presented in Table 5 (Figure S2). The correlation of the diameter with the molecular weight revealed a trend confirming the LSPR shift: an increase in Mw corresponded to larger nanoparticles (Fig. 4B). In this case, the polymer layer thickness around the metal nanoparticles (Table 4) exhibits a good correlation with the molecular weight of polymeric ligand employed. In particular, an increase of chain length corresponds to coherent thickening of polymer layer. Furthermore, XPS spectroscopy confirmed the presence of only Au0 on the catalyst surface (Figure S3). Following the same characterization procedure described in the previous sections, UV-visible spectroscopy was employed to assess the shift in the Localized Surface Plasmon Resonance (LSPR) absorption towards the red region (Fig. 5 ) of the PVAm-based Au NPs. In this case, a shift was observed, particularly when increasing the amount of amine moieties, resulting in a red shift of the LPR absorption peak. To confirm this trend, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were acquired, and the results are reported in Table 6 , which highlights that an increase in the amount of PVAm corresponds to the formation of larger gold nanoparticles, (Figure S1). Furthermore, the previously observed trend of increased Au particle size with higher molecular weight was confirmed, although the effect was less pronounced. The colloidal stability was evaluated by ξ potential analysis and the measurements conducted on the solutions exhibited good zeta potential values and therefore good stability of the system. To further characterize the materials, XPS analysis was carried out and the spectroscopic data are reported in the following Table 6. Focusing on Au4f7/2 peak, a decrease of BE was observed respect with the other systems with a shift from 84.1 to 83.7 eV, suggesting the presence of Au nanoparticles with a negative charge (Auδ-) (Table 6,) (Figure S3) [29,30]. The trend observed could be due to the electron-donor nature of amino groups as previously it has been reported for other polymers, such as PVP that contain N atom [31]. Typically, nitrogen-based ligands can interact with gold by partially covalent interaction due to the back-bonding mechanism between Au orbitals and nitrogen anti-bonding orbitals, which can suggest a modification of charge distribution in gold metal bonds [32,33]. The evaluation of polymer layer thickness highlighted the same trend observed as in the case of the PEO-based catalysts, where the Mw of the polymeric ligands has a strong influence on the thickness of the polymeric brush. The samples with different molecular weights (PVA-, PEO-, PVAm-based catalysts) were compared to understand the effect of this parameter as a function of Au mean nanoparticle size (Fig. 6 ). The graph highlights that using PEO as ligands leads obtaining Au particles with larger dimensions, despite the use of macromolecules with low molecular weight (e.g., 200 or 900 Mw). This can be attributed to the chemical nature of the ligands, classified as strong base, and therefore capable of forming only ionogenic interactions with the soft gold metal [34]. Furthermore, the absence of functional groups in the side chains that can efficiently coordinate the metal could be the main reason for promoting the growth of Au nanoparticles, resulting in an increase in their particle size. PVA-based materials exhibited an increase in Au particle size with increasing molecular weight, but the trend observed was less pronounced than that in the case of PEO series. On the other hand, PVAm-based catalysts had approximately the same Au nanoparticle dimensions (4–5 nm), with a slight increase in the system prepared with higher Mw. This behavior can be explained by bond strength, indeed amines (considered as a borderline soft/hard bases) can interact with partially covalent bonds with the gold metal and therefore act as stronger ligands compared to PVA or PEO [35,36]. As a result, the particles can strongly coordinate with the polymer, limiting their growth and therefore minimizing the effect connected to the molecular weight. 3.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic materials prepared using polymeric ligands with different molecular weight were tested for the model 4-nitrophenol reduction to evaluate how the Mw can influence their activity [37,38]. The outcomes are reported in Fig. 7 and Table 7 , (Figure S7). The analysis of the results reveals the following trend: as the length of the macromolecules involved increased, the apparent kinetic constant (kapp), used as a parameter to compare catalytic activity, decreased. This trend is especially pronounced in the case of PEO-based materials, with a difference of one order of magnitude between systems with low and higher molecular weights. Despite the lower kinetic constant values in the PVAm series, also in this case the trend was confirmed. The decrease in catalytic activity can be attributed to the strength of the ligands adsorbed on the catalyst's surface. The amine-based systems form pseudo-covalent interactions with the gold due to their borderline hardness/softness chemical nature. Moreover, the adsorbed energy of the amine groups on the low coordinative defective sites of the nanoparticles could hinder the chemisorption of 4-NP on the catalyst surface and therefore as a consequence a lower catalytic activity was observed. Concerning the PVA-based catalysts, all samples exhibited low activity, likely attributed to the site-blocking effect caused by the abundance of hydroxyl groups. The presence of hydrophilic groups on the macromolecules could facilitate the formation of brush-like structures, limiting the diffusion of reagents [39,40]. Furthermore, the brush thickness is dependent on the molecular weight, so a denser layer can be achieved with higher molecular weights, intensifying its effect on the catalytic performance [39]. The same behaviour can be the cause of the PVAm-based materials catalytic properties, but in this case, the chemical nature of the amine group could plays a crucial role to tune catalytic activity. The distinctions highlighted between PEO- and PVA-based materials can be attributed to variations in polymer adsorption energy. To support this hypothesis, Liuzzi and coworkers utilized DFT calculations to showcase the differences in adsorption energy and Au-O bond distance when PVA or PEO segments interacted with a gold cluster simulating gold nanoparticles, The results indicated a slight increase in adsorption in the case of the PEO system. A stronger adsorption energy signifies enhanced electronic involvement, suggesting that PEO ligands are more electron-donating than PVA [41]. Consequently, nanoparticles exhibit higher electron density, leading to increased catalytic activity. The presence of amines could enhance this behaviour, but the formation of brush-like structures limits the diffusion step, thereby restricting catalytic activity, therefore a balance must be found between these two parameters for leading to enhanced catalytic activity. Despite these results, the same trend related to the molecular weight effect is evident. The main message from the observed results is that the use of polymer chains with a higher molecular weight resulted in the formation of Au nanoparticles with a larger Au particle size. With increased dimensions, the surface Au area is expected to decrease leading to an observed loss in terms of catalytic properties, (Fig. 8 ). On the other hand, increasing the length of the macromolecular chains results in the formation of a thick polymer “brush” around the metal nanoparticles. This hinders the diffusion of reagents from the environment to the catalyst surface, leading to a decline in catalytic performance, (Fig. 9 ). To elucidate the reasons behind the loss in catalytic activity when the molecular weight increases, the impact of varying the Au/polymer weight ratio (ranging from 0.15 to 0.65) on the catalysts was investigated. The variation of Au/polymer weight ratio can influence the amount of polymer on the catalyst surface, and therefore could play a crucial role in determining the catalytic performance by affecting the availability of active sites and the reagent diffusion. In our previous work, we have deep investigated this parameter for PVA ligands comparing it with size and catalytic performance [23]. To extend the study and rationalize a general behaviour that can be explain in a robust manner the effect of polymer in colloidal nanocatalyst design, PVAm- and PEO-based samples were prepared by changing the amount of ligand. The samples PVAm1 and PEO1 were specifically chosen due to their small average Au nanoparticle size, aiming to explore the influence of this parameter. Notably, the catalytic performance showed improvement as the Au/polymer weight ratio decreased (Figure S7). For instance, the supported Au-PVAm nanoparticles with a ratio of 1:0.15 exhibited an apparent kinetic constant of 2.6·10−1 min−1, surpassing the values for catalysts prepared with ratios of 1:0.65 (5.6·10−2 min−1) and 1:0.33 (3.4 0·10−2 min−1) by more than tenfold. The observed rise in the apparent rate constant compared to other PVAm-based catalysts affirms the substantial role of polymeric stabilizers in influencing the availability of Au active sites. Instead, in the PEO-based catalysts not a significantly change in the catalytic performance can be observed changing Au:polymer ratio respect to PVA and PVAm series, highlighting the substantial role of the ligand chemical nature. The catalysts synthesized varying Au:polymer weight ratios were characterized thorough to elucidate the observed catalytic performance, (Table 8 ). TEM analysis corroborated the slight enlargement of Au nanoparticle size, particularly evident in samples with lower polymer content, (Figure S4). Instead, XPS spectra confirmed the presence of metallic Au on the catalyst surface, without highlighting a significant correlation between Au:polymer ratio and surface exposure of Au, (Figure S6). Notably, variations in the polymer amount significantly affected the thickness of the polymer layer. A reduction in the quantity of polymeric ligands on the surface led to a thinner polymer brush, which is a key factor influencing catalytic activity. A decrease in the packing density of the polymer layer around the nanoparticles facilitated the diffusion of reagents to the active sites, thereby enhancing catalytic performance, explaining the observed influence on catalytic activity, (Fig. 10 ). 4 Conclusions This research focused on investigating how hydro-soluble polymeric ligands impact the properties (such as Au nanoparticle size and dispersion) and catalytic performance (conversion and selectivity) of colloidal gold nanoparticles supported on activated carbon. The main goal was to understand how polymeric ligands influence these parameters, establishing a method to optimize catalysis during the design phase. To achieve this, three different polymeric ligands (PVA, PEO, and PVAm) with various molecular weights were synthesized through controlled chain-transfer-to-solvent reactions to tune the final molecular weights. These ligands were then used to prepare supported colloidal Au nanoparticles via sol-immobilization. Comparing the three catalyst types (PVA-, PEO-, and PVAm-based), molecular weight was found to significantly affect the Au nanoparticle size. PEO ligands produced larger nanoparticles, even at lower molecular weights (e.g., 200 or 900 Da), due to their hard base character, which forms mainly ionogenic interactions with gold (soft centre) following HSAB theory and lacks functional groups to coordinate the metal efficiently. Instead, PVA- and PVAm-based catalysts showed a less pronounced increase in nanoparticle size with increasing molecular weight. In the case of PVAm-system, this behavior was attributed to stronger coordination between amine groups and gold, forming partially covalent bonds that limit nanoparticle growth. To evaluate the effect of molecular weight on catalytic activity, the catalysts were tested for 4-nitrophenol (4-NP) reduction chose as a model reaction. As polymer molecular weight increased, the apparent kinetic constant (kapp) decreased, reflecting reduced catalytic activity. This trend was particularly noticeable in PEO-based catalysts, with kapp values decreasing by an order of magnitude between low and high molecular weights. PVAm-based catalysts also exhibited a decline in activity, though to a lesser extent. The reduction in catalytic performance was linked to stronger ligand-metal interactions, particularly in amine-based systems where pseudo-covalent bonds hindered 4-NP chemisorption. Additionally, higher molecular weight polymers formed dense polymeric "brushes" around the nanoparticles, limiting reagent diffusion and further reducing activity. Increased Au nanoparticle size with larger macromolecules also reduced the available surface area, rationalizing the loss in catalytic efficiency. Further investigation into the Au/polymer weight ratio (0.15 to 0.65) revealed that lowering the polymer content enhanced catalytic performance by improving reagent diffusion. This was particularly evident in Au-PVAm catalysts, where a 1:0.15 ratio yielded a much higher apparent kinetic constant (2.6·10−1 min−1) compared to catalysts with higher polymer content. TEM and XPS analyses confirmed a slight increase in Au nanoparticle size but found no significant correlation between Au/polymer ratio and surface exposure of Au. A thinner polymer brush at lower polymer content facilitated reagent access, explaining the observed improvement in catalytic activity. The outcomes revealed the critical role of the polymeric ligands in the colloidal nano-catalyst design and activity. In particular, the polymer molecular weight represents a crucial aspect during the material design, highlighting the necessity to deeply investigate the metal-polymer interface chemistry to model and improve the final properties. coredata.dc:description: This research investigates the influence of hydro-soluble polymeric ligands on the properties and catalytic performance of colloidal gold nanoparticles supported on activated carbon. The aim was to understand how polymer molecular weight affects Au nanoparticle size, dispersion, and catalytic activity, providing a framework for optimizing catalysis from the design phase. Three polymeric ligands (PVA, PEO, and PVAm) with different molecular weights were synthesized via controlled chain-transfer-to-solvent reactions and used to prepare supported colloidal Au nanoparticles through sol-immobilization. The results demonstrated that molecular weight significantly impacts Au nanoparticle size. Moreover, catalytic activity was assessed using the reduction of 4-nitrophenol as a model reaction. As polymer molecular weight increased, the apparent kinetic constant (kapp) decreased, particularly for PEO-based catalysts, where kapp decreased by an order of magnitude. Higher molecular weight polymers also formed dense polymeric "brushes," hindering reagent diffusion and reducing catalytic performance. Further analysis of Au/polymer weight ratios revealed that decreasing polymer content improved catalytic activity, particularly in Au-PVAm catalysts. The findings underscore the crucial role of polymeric ligands in colloidal nanocatalyst design, emphasizing the need to investigate the metal-polymer interface to optimize catalyst properties.
